featured.text: The researchers found that the parts of the brain involved in learning, memory, emotion, and touch became more active as the volunteers expected higher levels of pain.
They are very active in the daytime.
Regular exercisers, furthermore, are found to be about 30 percent less active on days when they exercise.
Researchers further point out that in most people synesthesia is active only during the first months of their infancy, while this ability remains forever in certain individuals.

other.text: This allowed Hirsch to see which parts of the brain were getting more blood and were more active.
These were mainly the same areas that became active when participants actually felt pain.
